messageBody:
Aimee,

This sounds like a class loader problem to me. Which ui are you using for
JUnit? If using swingui, try editing your excluded.properties file to
exclude your helper class.

-Jason

> -----Original Message-----
> From: Aimee Ukasick [mailto:aimee.ukasick@...]
> Sent: Friday, July 20, 2001 9:44 AM
> To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> Subject: [junit] Problem Loading Properties Files with JUnit
>
>
> I am having a very annoying problem when I use JUnit.
> I have a helper class that loads a properties file. I
> wrote a simple class with a main to test calling the
> helper class and loading the file, and
> the file IS found and loaded without a problem. However,
> when I use a JUnit test to call the code that calls the
> helper class, the properties
> file IS NOT found. But if I put the method to load the
> properties file INSIDE the JUnit test class, the file IS
> found and loaded.
>
> The directory stucture where the classes, config files,
> and lib sits is:
> build
> ->classes->com
> ->config
> ->lib
> The lib folder contains junit.jar, and config has the
> properties file. Both the Windows system classpath and
> the IDE's classpath point to
> build/classes and the jar files. I have the same problem
> whether I run from a command line or within the IDE.
>
> Here is the method to load the properties (this works
> when not using JUnit):
> private void loadProperties() {
> InputStream in = null;
> in =
> this.getClass().getResourceAsStream("/config/aoi.properties");
> if (in == null) {
> if (
> Logger.getInstance().isDebugEnabled() ) {
>
> Logger.getInstance().getCat().fatal("Unable to load
> properties -- using defaults");
> remoteRegistryPort = 1099;
> remoteRegistryServer = "localhost";
> }else {
>
> Logger.getInstance().getCat().fatal("Unable to load properties");
> return;
> }
> }else {
> props.load(in);
> }
> }catch(IOException e) {
>
> Logger.getInstance().getCat().fatal("RMIHelper: Unable to
> load properties. "+e.getMessage()+" SHUTTING DOWN");
>
> }finally {
> if (in != null) {
> try {
> in.close();
> }catch(Exception e) {
>
> Logger.getInstance().debug("Unable to close InputStream");
> }
> }
> }
> }
>
> Does anyone know why the properties file does not load
> when I call the helper class from within a JUnit test? Is
> this a ClassLoader
> problem? If it is, why does the ClassLoader start looking
> in a different place when I use JUnit? How do I fix this
> so I can have unittests that
> run successfully?
> Any help is greatly appreciated!!
>
